sec.p: In 2010, nematode egg counts before treatment did not differ between drug-treated and control shag chick groups (−0.2 ± 0.9, χ = 0.03, df = 1, P = 0.865), but 5–15 days after treatment, drug-treated chicks released significantly fewer eggs than control chicks (−3.7 ± 0.9; χ = 8.5, df = 1, P < 0.001). Chicks of different rank did not differ in their fecal egg counts before or after treatment (before, χ = 1.08, df = 4, P = 0.897; A chicks: 0.15 ± 0.11; B chicks: 0.09 ± 0.06; C chicks: 0.05 ± 0.05; after, rank-by-treatment interaction for both B and C chicks compared to A, P > 0.8; main effect of rank in addition to treatment, B and C chicks both P > 0.2 compared to A). Parasite burdens did not differ between years (as a categorical main effect, 2010–2012 only, χ = 1.58, df = 2, P = 0.453).
